ers appear to have resources for dealing with their difficulties
that opponents of abortion lack. Consider their moral-relevance problem. A
pro-choicer might argue that morality rests on contractual foundations and
that only those who have the psychological attributes of persons are capable
of entering into the moral contract and, as a consequence, being a member
of the moral community. (This is essentially Engelhardt’s [1986] view.) The
